speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We’ll hear argument this morning in Case 09-337, Krupski v. Costa Crociere, S.p.A. Mr. Bendure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you know, Mr. Bendure, what exactly the corporate relationship was between the two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, your -- your client tripped over the cable, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if the case were there were two people behind her and she was pushed? And she didn't know which one pushed her, Jones or Smith. So she sues Jones, and Smith knows all about it because, of course, he's a key witness or whatever. Can he be substituted later on because he was the person she should have sued?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Not just the real name. It's not that Jones pushed her, but his real name is Johnson. It's that Jones -- whoever pushed her; I forget -- but one guy -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: One of the people pushed her, and she named that -- she named the other person. She made a mistake about who pushed her. Can they have substitution in that case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes. The non-pusher has notice --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- and everything else. But there’s no relationship between the two of them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What was the first -- when was your first notice of that? I mean, it was on the first page of the ticket, but the answer came after the statute of limitations. Was that your first notice that there was this different entity, or did you know that earlier?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you don't -- I didn't understand you to deny that the ticket made it very clear who operated the ship.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you contest that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why not? Don't you read the contract carefully before you bring a lawsuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you are -- you either are contesting or you’re not contesting that it's clear from the ticket. I had assumed it was clear from the ticket.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you had -- so then you had notice even before the suit was filed. It was on the -- it was on the ticket.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the -- did the name show up any place other than page 1 of the general conditions of passage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's -- and this is what? An 11-page, very small print --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not -- not if you read the definitions on page 1. And if you are not going to read all 11 pages before you file suit, I would think you would at least read page 1. And that, it seems to me, made it clear.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let me -- I’ve been thinking about the Chief Justice's question where the two people are pushed and you don't know which person -- or two people fired the shotgun, and there’s only one pellet, and you don't know which gun the pellet came from. In that case, I think we could stipulate that even by reasonable inquiry, you wouldn't know. In your case, I think the -- and I think the difference in the case is that "reasonable inquiry" means you should have known. So now we have a rule that excuses something you should have known but doesn't excuse something you -- you couldn't have known, which seems odd. And because it's odd, therefore, maybe that's why it only applies to clerical errors.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- assume I accept your argument, and I am the cruise operator -- the cruise owner, cruise ship owner, and I look at the complaint, and I say: I think they really meant me, but -- I think. Now, within the 4(m) period, which is the period in which I am supposed to reasonably know that I would have been named absent a mistake, here an answer is filed, and you are told there is a mistake, and you don't correct the mistake. What conclusion would a reasonable person at that second juncture make about whether you made a mistake or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And I think that's what the issue is here, which is, assuming the complaint could be read as a mistake during the 4(m) period, wasn't that mistake corrected, and you refused or failed to act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That makes so little sense to me. Here I think -- and for the following reason: You seriously I don't think could contend that if you had sought to amend a year later, that that would have been timely, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. But putting aside prejudice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- what the lower court said was because your delay speaks to a choice, that that's the only thing a reasonable defendant would have assumed, that having been told that you sued the wrong party and you continued in that action, that that's what you intended to do, to sue that wrong party.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Bendure, would you explain one factual matter to me? I might have gotten this wrong, but I thought the answer was filed after the 1 year had run.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So when the answer was filed it was too late for you to come within the statute of limitations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I thought that would be the answer that you would give to Justice Sotomayor, because when you got the answer -- which was filed after how many days?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If you had gotten that a few days earlier, you could have amended, and then we wouldn't be here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. You have 120 days to amend, don't you, from the filing of the complaint?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Complaint.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the basic point is the answer didn't come in until you were already out under the statute of limitations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So from their point of view, nothing else matters; you were out when they filed their answer, and you could do nothing to cure that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Did your amended complaint contain any new and material allegations other than the name correction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought that the only condition was that it had to arise out of the same event or transaction, which would give you much more running room than -- than what you assert.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Bendure, in addition to the mailing of the ticket -- the mailing of the ticket came; it said "Costa Cruise" -- were there any other connections between the plaintiff passenger and Costa Cruise beyond the ticket coming in an envelope that says "Costa Cruise"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Bendure, can -- can I come back to your -- I'm not sure why it matters, but it seems to me you’re giving too narrow an interpretation, and I would not like our opinion to read any more narrowly than the statute allows. It seems to me that if you assert a different claim arising out of the same transaction, you would be able to amend. If you will look at (c)(1)(C), which is what you’re asserting here, right? (C)(1)(C) says, “the amendment changes the party or the naming of party against whom the claim is asserted, if Rule 15(c)(1)(B) is satisfied.” Then you go back to (1)(B) and it says, “the amendment asserts a claim or defense that arose out of the conduct, transaction, or occurrence set out.” It doesn't say it has to be the same claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand that. That's why I don't understand why you’re arguing a more narrow -- a more narrow interpretation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me you’re home free with (B).

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, yes, but -- but those are the only things we -- we have to argue about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There’s no doubt that you are asserting -- even if you were asserting a different claim, it certainly arose out of the same transaction or event, didn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Glazier.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Glazier --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's no mistake if you happen to know it, if you happen to know who the right party is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ever?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Have you ever driven a car where your wife has said turn left and you’ve turned right? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Has that ever happened to you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Was there anything you didn't know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I'm asking about this question, my hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Was there anything you didn't know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Correct. Did you do it by mistake? Yes, of course, you did. It's happened to every human being. There are millions of instances in which people do things by mistake where, in fact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think your wife made a mistake. I don't think you made a mistake. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, my wife does not make mistakes. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I make mistakes, and sometimes I make mistakes knowing all the facts, and so do you and so does everybody else. So I never heard of this thing that you can't make a mistake knowing all the facts. But anyway, here we have a person who didn't know all the facts. What the judge says is he should have known all the facts. Where in the record does he say he did know all the facts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's a different matter. My wife told me to turn left and I turned right, okay? But I didn't take it in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that's a different matter. Where does it say that he did know the facts as opposed to he should have known the facts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I just want the citations to the page. I wasn't challenging you. I just wanted the citations to the page --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- where there’s a finding that, in fact, he knew that this company called "Costa Cruise" in Italian is the same as the company called "Costa Cruise" in English? I take it "Crociere" means "cruise."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, yes. One is called "Costa Cruise" in Italian and one is called "Costa Cruise" in English. And I just want to know where it says in the record that the client or he, the lawyer, actually knew, actually knew that he should have sued the one that spells its name in Italian?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I didn't ask you that question. I'm asking for a record citation as to where there is a finding that this particular plaintiff knew that the Italian company called "Costa Cruise" was in fact the one he should have sued?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I’ll write them down and look at them later.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: 19a of the petition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought what the district court said was “impute” the knowledge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it say that? Where does it say that on 19a?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I -- I know. I would say in reading this, that both courts have made the most elementary mistake of the English language in thinking that when a person doesn't know something but should have known it, that that’s inconsistent with a mistake. That's the very definition of a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, all I want is some citation from you that shows that isn't what they thought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's the conclusion, and when I read two sentences down, it said they may have had constructive knowledge. The word "constructive" to me, when I hear I want to run out the door, because what the word "constructive" to me means is not knowledge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm sorry. I -- I am not following it. Where -- where -- where --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm on page 19a.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. But he's talking about constructive notice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Constructive notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- by -- by the defendant, not constructive knowledge by the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Then what is -- where is the page that it says that the plaintiff had actual, as opposed to imputed, knowledge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is there any other than that one page on the ticket, that against the mailing envelopes that she got that say "Costa Cruise" -- is there anything in the entire record other than that definition page that includes carrier, that includes steward, anything else that tips her off that this is a different corporation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It says it includes stewards. What do you -- what do you say to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It includes the stewards on the boat, according to your -- your friend.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why can't Costa Cruise be perceived to hold one of those roles?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the relationship between those corporations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But are they -- are they sister corporations, a parent-sub --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: When it's below them, you mean it owns all the shares in its -- in its subsidiary company?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You know, the -- the definition of carrier includes independent contractors. I mean -- I -- I would -- other than that they are more closely related, I can see someone thinking, well, Costa Cruise is at least an independent contractor with which Costa Crociere does business.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And if you went to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If you went to the Web site, which was mentioned, for Costa Cruise, there would be a tab that says "Our ships" "Our ships" -- and one of those ships is Costa Magica, whatever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: "Our ships," and it identifies Costa Cruise as the cruise operator. That's the information that's given to passengers in the United States who are going to book on these ships. It says Costa Cruise, our ships, Costa Cruise is the operator. That's what was being put forth to the public.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So it shouldn't matter that this confusion was caused in large part by this entity that advertises in English under the name "Costa Cruise" and identifies Costa Cruise as the operator. "The largest European cruise operator" is how Costa Cruise is -- is identified in -- in the advertising.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the answer is filed conveniently after the 1-year period has run.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but I don't -- I mean, there’s some sharp practice going on here. Paragraph 10 of their complaint sues Costa Cruise Lines because -- saying they owned, operated, managed, supervised, and controlled the ocean-going passenger vessel. And it's the same lawyer for Costa Cruise as for Costa Crociere, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. So that lawyer looks at this and says: Aha, they made a mistake; they named the cruise line rather than the name in Italian. So I'm going to wait until the statute of limitations runs, and then a couple of days after, I'm going to say aha.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the answer say the statute -- the 1-year period has run? Was that raised as a defense in the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: When was it raised as a defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that -- the Rule 4(m) period concerns when you can serve. It doesn't say that the statute of limitations is any more than what was the term of the -- of the passage, was 1 year.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, that -- that assumes -- that assumes -- when, what is it, 1(C)(ii), "knew or should have known," it says within the period provided by rule 4(m). Now, in the early part of that period, at -- at one point in the period you should have known. And at another point, because the answer was filed, you shouldn't have known.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you're relying on the fact that they filed an answer which -- I'm sorry -- that -- that you filed an answer which made it very clear to them what the situation was. But was there any point, any -- and all it takes I think is any point within that 4(m) period -- when you -- you knew or should have known?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where -- where is the defense -- I mean, the ticket says suit must be filed within 1 year of the date of any alleged injury. And where is the -- that defense stated? You said it comes up 10 weeks --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- being realistic about it, as I understand it you're relying entirely on the condition, general conditions of passage in the ticket, the fine print describing the term "carrier." That's -- but do you take into account that the cover of the ticket, which is what the passenger would look at, uses "Costa Cruises," blah, blah, blah -- "Costa Cruise Lines" and so -- and doesn't even mention the carrier?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Don't you think, looking at that ticket, if you were a passenger you would think you were doing business with Costa Cruise?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Just looking at the cover?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Am I correct that on the cover of the ticket, the Italian name isn't used at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And isn't that what the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- what the passenger would normally look at, understand who he is doing business with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Assuming -- assuming the lawyer would just look at the cover before he files a lawsuit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand what the lawyer reading the ticket has to do with this question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because the question is whether the lawyer made a mistake. Isn't that the question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And he did make a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That isn't true, is it? In the English language, it's not true? I mean, that's why I was giving you some examples. I don't know; maybe there’s some special legal language somewhere written in Blackstone, or maybe it's Lord Coke, I don't know, that says when you use the word "mistake" don't use it in English, use -- use it in Italian. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I mean, if we're going to use it in English, there -- it's not hard to find instances where a person would know, but he'd still make a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And there's even a fortiori --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- if he doesn't know, even if he should.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Isn't that true?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What possible reason is there that somebody who is hurt on a ship and has a lawyer, and she has a broken leg, and she'd like to get recovery, would deliberately sue the wrong person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is there such a reason?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I’m just saying, did he do it by mistake? If you were representing this person, would you want to sue the company that could give you some money if they are liable? Or would you rather sue the Bank of America that has nothing to do with it? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I want to ask you about that, because in your brief you refer in your footnote on page 6 to requirements of the Federal Government 44101-44103. So I looked those up. I discovered that 44103 says that it is a requirement, and you say you follow these requirements, that you shall establish under regulations of the FMC financial responsibility. And those regulations tell you that, at least as best I could read them, that you must furnish a written designation of a person in the United States as a legal agent for service of process, and they are referring to instances in which somebody on a ship suffered an accident. So since you say that you are complying with that, I would like to know the name and address of that person in the United States for whom you must send legal process, because if obviously that had been on the ticket, that is precisely the man to whom this plaintiff would have sent the notice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well then, were you correct when you said in your -- in your brief that this company which you represent does comply with 44103?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It is relevant, I think, because it adds to the confusion if they are under a legal requirement to have a service -- an agent to receive service, and then they not only don't do it, but they don't have it printed on the ticket. And they get everybody mixed up by having the same name in English, or a very similar one, and announcing someone you’re supposed to serve, and then it turns out to be not that person you’re supposed to serve. It's a mysterious person that you can't find.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It seems odd. I’d like to know what the explanation is of this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we -- let's clarify that point now. I am looking at 3a, which is the court of appeals opinion, and it says that "Costa Crociere moved to dismiss, arguing that it had been sued after the 1-year ticket period allowed for claims set forth" -- as set forth in the ticket. Then the rule tells us that you have this much time to serve, and then the complaint will -- the -- the amendment will relate back to the date of the original filing. It doesn't change your statement, your defense. The 1-year statute of limitations isn't affected. What is affected is the complaint will relate back if there’s an amendment filed. But the 1-year statute of limitations remains, and you didn't bother to answer until the -- that time had run.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but the relation back is different from the point at which the statute has run. The statute runs after 1 year. Then, if she does what the rules say, it can relate back to the date of the original filing. The fact remains that you didn't file your answer until after the limitation period had run.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why does that even matter? I'm not really sure I'm following this argument. Let's say that the answer was filed during the limitations period, and the lawyer -- the plaintiff's lawyer is a solo practitioner, and he or she is out of the office because the lawyer's on a cruise -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- and doesn't come back for 2 weeks. And by that time, the limitations period has run. It's still a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Where do you see in -- the question on which cert was granted has to do with imputed knowledge. Where do you see in the text of this rule anything that picks up the concept of either imputed knowledge or actual knowledge? It just talks about a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, where -- just -- where do you -- where in the rule is there anything that relates to the reasonableness of the mistake? What if it is the most foolish, negligent mistake you can possibly imagine? Is it not still a mistake?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That’s not what the rule says. That’s not what the rule says. The rule doesn't talk about what kind of mistake or why. The rule says what the defendant should have known. And so, when you read this complaint, it's very clear you know you’re the carrier.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You know cruise -- the other line, the sales agent, can't be the carrier, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So it's either a factual or a legal mistake. There is no other way to read that other than that there is a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Because -- then have you to answer Justice Breyer's question, which is: What conceivable reason that is not either negligence or unintentional or inadvertent or just plain stupidity, however you want to define it, that someone who is injured would want to name a party who wasn't responsible for the injury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, that's evidence from which the absence of a mistake might be inferred. I agree with that, but that doesn't establish that it wasn't -- it wasn't a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But, counsel, don't -- what you’re really talking about is whether once the answer was filed, they were dilatory in making their motion. I don't understand how you can argue that the day you received this complaint, you didn't understand that some sort of mistake had been made. The day that the answer came in, you might start to have a doubt because of their delay in the motion to amend, but doesn't that go to a 15(a) question, whether the judge should have given leave to amend because of dilatory tactics? Isn't that a 15(a) question, not a 15(c) question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is there anything in the face of the complaint that would suggest anything but a mistake? Now, forget -- I'm being very specific. On the face of the complaint. You read that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Where does it say that? Where does it say: "I know that the carrier is Costa Crociere"? Where does it say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What the complaint says is that Costa Cruise, the operator of the vessel, injured me, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And is that an accurate statement of fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, I would have said the previous paragraph, 9, says: "The plaintiff has complied with all the pre-suit requirements of the passenger ticket." So you know they read the ticket.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Now, which is it? Is that a Freudian slip? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Just a mistake. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Despite that, they made a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They made a mistake, right? They read the ticket, and despite that, they made a mistake.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Why isn't -- why doesn't the rule cover it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I object to your relying upon the -- the answer as -- as establishing compliance with (C)(ii), because (C), in the prologue, says "is satisfied, if within the period provided by Rule 4(m)." And there is at least some point within that period before the answer was filed. And if, within that period before the answer, you knew or should have known that it was a mistake, it seems to me you lose. Do you understand what I'm saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the -- the only thing you could rely on for that short period before the answer is filed is simply the ticket, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you are reading "within the period" to mean "throughout the period." It doesn't say “throughout the period.” It says “if within the period.”

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think it's an important issue with respect to the statute. I don't think we can treat cavalierly whether "within the period" means "throughout the period." That's one of the issues here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have one -- one question about the face of the ticket, the one with the picture on it. Is it Costa Cruise or Costa Crociere that got this big award for “B.E.S.T. 4”?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Pardon me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I make the assumption that it's the cruise line, Crociere, that got the award. So the ticket itself confuses the two companies. Is that a mistake, incidentally? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If I am right, is that a mistake?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How many -- if you have a 1,000-page ticket, how many pages do you have to read?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But this is the first one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The one I pointed out to you with the mistake, that’s the first one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm still puzzled, because Rule (C) just requires -- describes the state of mind of the defendant, correct? C(i) and (ii); isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And is it not true that under (i), the defendant did receive such notice of the action, would not be prejudiced? That's clear, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And is it also true that at the time they received the complaint, they knew or should have known that the action would have been brought against the carrier instead of the broker?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I just don't understand how you get around the plain language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You don't think -- you don't think that the agent didn't realize that they would have sued the carrier if they had known the identity of the right party?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I understand all that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But we're talking about the -- about mindset of the defendant, and to say that they wouldn't have sued -- they would have sued the broker instead of this carrier? It's absurd.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Bendure, you have 9 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This is sort of an equitable rule, isn't it, this mistake? We're going to, you know -- equity takes account of such things. It seems to me very reasonable to say: If the mistake is egregious, it doesn't apply.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would have thought your answer would have been: This has nothing to do with equity at all. It's just the interpretation of a legal rule.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This might be tangential, but is there a reason to suggest the Federal Maritime Commission look into this? Because I read the regs. I don't understand quite what's going on, because it seems to me they have a rule that is designed to prevent this situation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that true, what I'm suggesting or not? You know the area better.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
